questions.text: What is biology the scientific study of?
Which of the following questions might a biologist ask?
choices: How does a single cell develop into an organism?
How does the human mind work?
How do different forms of life in a forest interact?

questions.text: What is a fundamental principle of biology?
What do adaptations of organisms to their environment result from?
What is a unifying theme in biology that helps organize biological information?
Life can be studied at different levels, from:
choices: Cells to the entire living planet
questions.correctAnswer: Cells to the entire living planet

questions.text: What is the correct order of the levels of biological organization from smallest to largest?
Which of the following is the most inclusive level of biological organization?
What is reductionism in the context of studying complex systems?
choices: Expanding the system to include more components
Reducing complex systems to simpler components
Studying the system as a whole without breaking it down
questions.correctAnswer: Reducing complex systems to simpler components

questions.text: The scientific study of life is called:
What is the process of change that has resulted in the astounding array of organisms found on Earth?
Which domains consist of prokaryotes?
Which of the following eukaryotic kingdoms includes organisms that produce their own food by photosynthesis?
What is the role of fungi in the domain Eukarya?
choices: Produce their own food by photosynthesis
Obtain food by eating and digesting other organisms
Carry out photosynthesis in aquatic environments

questions.text: What is the universal genetic language common to all organisms?
What reflects the inheritance of a limb structure from a common ancestor?
choices: The shared anatomy of mammalian limbs
questions.correctAnswer: The shared anatomy of mammalian limbs

questions.text: The remarkably diverse forms of life on this planet arose by what processes?
What led to a reevaluation of larger groupings of classifying the diversity of life?
choices: Careful analysis of form and function
New methods of assessing species relationships
questions.correctAnswer: New methods of assessing species relationships

questions.text: What is the directional change in global climate that lasts three decades or more?
Scientists calculate that the CO2 that human activities have added to the atmosphere has increased the average temperature of the planet by how much since 1900?
What accounts for both the *unity and diversity of life*?
The evolutionary relationships are illustrated with what?
Similar traits in two species are explained by what?
Differences between two species indicate that what has occurred after divergence from a common ancestor?
What did Darwin propose could cause an ancestral species to give rise to two or more descendant species?
The finch species of the Galápagos Islands are descended from what?
choices: A separate creation event for each species

questions.text: The shared anatomy of mammalian limbs reflects what?
choices: Inheritance of a limb structure from a common ancestor
questions.correctAnswer: Inheritance of a limb structure from a common ancestor

questions.text: What process accounts for the remarkably diverse forms of life on this planet?
What is the mechanism of evolutionary adaptation?
What is natural selection?
choices: A process where humans choose desired traits
The natural environment 'selects' for advantageous traits
questions.correctAnswer: The natural environment 'selects' for advantageous traits

questions.text: In the context of natural selection, what tends to happen over many generations?
choices: More individuals in a population will have the advantageous traits
questions.correctAnswer: More individuals in a population will have the advantageous traits

questions.text: According to Darwin's observations, what is inevitable due to the production of more offspring than can survive?
What was one of Darwin's main points in 'On the Origin of Species'?
choices: Species showed evidence of 'descent with modification' from common ancestors
Evolution is driven by random chance
questions.correctAnswer: Species showed evidence of 'descent with modification' from common ancestors

questions.text: What publication is credited to Charles Darwin in 1859?
choices: On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection
questions.correctAnswer: On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection

questions.text: Why is DNA considered a remarkable unity underlying the diversity of life?
choices: Because it is only found in certain organisms
Because it varies greatly between species
Because it is the universal genetic language common to all organisms
Because it is not subject to mutation
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is the universal genetic language common to all organisms

questions.text: What is the significance of fossils in understanding the unity and diversity of life?
choices: They provide evidence for a young Earth
They document the evolution of life on Earth over billions of years
They support the idea of fixed, unchanging species
They are irrelevant to the study of evolution
questions.correctAnswer: They document the evolution of life on Earth over billions of years

questions.text: How does natural selection lead to the diversity of mammalian limbs?
choices: By maintaining a uniform limb structure
By modification over millions of years
By preventing adaptation to different environments
questions.correctAnswer: By modification over millions of years

questions.text: What is the role of the natural environment in natural selection?
choices: It 'selects' for advantageous traits in the population [1]
questions.correctAnswer: It 'selects' for advantageous traits in the population [1]

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of natural selection?
choices: Increased frequency of traits -> reproduction of survivors -> elimination of individuals -> population with varied traits
Elimination of individuals -> reproduction of survivors -> population with varied traits -> increased frequency of traits
Population with varied traits -> elimination of individuals -> reproduction of survivors -> increased frequency of traits
Reproduction of survivors -> increased frequency of traits -> population with varied traits -> elimination of individuals
questions.correctAnswer: Population with varied traits -> elimination of individuals -> reproduction of survivors -> increased frequency of traits

questions.text: How does descent from a common ancestor explain the unity of life?
choices: It explains the independent origin of species
It suggests that all species have identical traits
It indicates that similar traits are inherited from a shared lineage
It implies that evolution does not occur
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates that similar traits are inherited from a shared lineage

questions.text: Which of the following organisms are considered producers in a community?
What is the role of consumers in a community?
choices: To convert sunlight into chemical energy

questions.text: Which process do producers use to create their own food?
Which of these organisms would be classified as a consumer?
In a forest community, which of the following is a producer?
What is the primary source of energy for producers in most communities?
Which of the following describes the flow of energy in a community?
What term describes an organism that obtains energy by feeding on producers?
Which of the following is an example of an interaction within a community?
choices: A plant taking up water from the soil

questions.text: What is the role of plants in a community?
In a prairie ecosystem, which organism is a producer?
Which term describes an organism that eats other consumers?
How do consumers obtain energy and matter?
choices: By absorbing it from the soil

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a producer?
What is the relationship between producers and consumers in a food chain?
Which organism converts the energy of sunlight into the chemical energy of sugars?
What is the ecological role of a primary consumer?
Which of the following organisms is capable of photosynthesis?
What best describes the interaction between organisms and their environment?
choices: Organisms do not affect their environment
Environments are affected by the organisms living in it
Organisms and their environments affect each other
questions.correctAnswer: Organisms and their environments affect each other

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a producer-consumer relationship?
What is the primary goal of the scientific method?
choices: To propose theories about the natural world
To gather data without a purpose
questions.correctAnswer: To propose theories about the natural world

questions.text: Which of the following is the first step in the scientific method?
What is a hypothesis in the context of the scientific method?
choices: An explanation based on observations and assumptions that leads to a testable prediction
questions.correctAnswer: An explanation based on observations and assumptions that leads to a testable prediction

questions.text: What is the purpose of an experiment in the scientific method?
In experimental design, what is a controlled experiment?
choices: An experiment with many uncontrolled variables
An experiment that compares an experimental group with a control group
questions.correctAnswer: An experiment that compares an experimental group with a control group

questions.text: What is the role of a control group in an experiment?
choices: To serve as a baseline for comparison
To introduce bias into the experiment
questions.correctAnswer: To serve as a baseline for comparison

questions.text: What is an independent variable in an experiment?
choices: The variable that is kept constant
The variable that is manipulated by the researcher
The variable that is not important
questions.correctAnswer: The variable that is manipulated by the researcher

questions.text: What is a dependent variable in an experiment?
choices: The effect of the manipulated factor
questions.correctAnswer: The effect of the manipulated factor

questions.text: Why is data analysis important in the scientific method?
choices: To interpret the results and draw conclusions
questions.correctAnswer: To interpret the results and draw conclusions

questions.text: What is inductive reasoning?
choices: Drawing conclusions from specific observations to make generalizations
Starting with a general premise to predict specific results
questions.correctAnswer: Drawing conclusions from specific observations to make generalizations

questions.text: What is deductive reasoning?
choices: Extrapolating from general premises to specific predictions
questions.correctAnswer: Extrapolating from general premises to specific predictions

questions.text: What makes a hypothesis testable and falsifiable?
choices: It is based on supernatural explanations
It can be tested through experiments or observations
It is outside the bounds of science
questions.correctAnswer: It can be tested through experiments or observations

questions.text: In science, what is a theory?
choices: A hypothesis that has not been tested
A broad explanation supported by a large body of evidence
questions.correctAnswer: A broad explanation supported by a large body of evidence

questions.text: Why is replication of experiments important in science?
choices: To confirm observations and ensure accuracy
questions.correctAnswer: To confirm observations and ensure accuracy

questions.text: What is the role of observation in scientific inquiry?
choices: To begin the process of scientific study
questions.correctAnswer: To begin the process of scientific study

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?
Which of the following is an example of quantitative data?
Why is it impossible to conclusively prove a hypothesis to be true?
choices: Because we can test all alternatives
Because a hypothesis is always true
Because we can never test all the alternatives
questions.correctAnswer: Because we can never test all the alternatives

questions.text: What does experimental design involve?
choices: Careful planning to eliminate bias and control variables
questions.correctAnswer: Careful planning to eliminate bias and control variables

questions.text: What role do past studies play in the scientific process?
choices: Scientists can build on the foundations of existing knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Scientists can build on the foundations of existing knowledge

questions.text: What is a chemical compound?
choices: A substance consisting of one element
A substance consisting of two or more elements in a fixed ratio
An element that cannot be broken down
questions.correctAnswer: A substance consisting of two or more elements in a fixed ratio

questions.text: What is an element?
choices: A substance that can be broken down chemically
A substance consisting of multiple compounds
A substance that cannot be broken down to other substances by chemical reactions
questions.correctAnswer: A substance that cannot be broken down to other substances by chemical reactions

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element?
What are the three subatomic particles that make up an atom?
What is the atomic number of an element?
choices: The sum of protons and neutrons in the nucleus
The number of neutrons in the nucleus
The number of protons in the nucleus
The number of electrons in the outer shell
questions.correctAnswer: The number of protons in the nucleus

questions.text: What is the mass number of an atom?
choices: The number of electrons in the atom
The number of protons in the atom
The sum of protons and neutrons in the nucleus
The average of all isotopes of an element
questions.correctAnswer: The sum of protons and neutrons in the nucleus

questions.text: What are isotopes?
choices: Atoms with the same number of neutrons but different numbers of protons
Atoms with the same number of protons but different numbers of electrons
Atoms with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons
questions.correctAnswer: Atoms with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons

questions.text: What are valence electrons?
choices: Electrons that occupy the valence shell
Electrons not involved in chemical bonding
questions.correctAnswer: Electrons that occupy the valence shell

questions.text: What determines the chemical behavior of an atom?
choices: The number of electrons in its outermost shell
questions.correctAnswer: The number of electrons in its outermost shell

questions.text: What is a covalent bond?
choices: The transfer of electrons between atoms
The sharing of a pair of valence electrons by two atoms
An attraction between ions of opposite charge
questions.correctAnswer: The sharing of a pair of valence electrons by two atoms

questions.text: What is electronegativity?
choices: An atom's ability to repel electrons
An atom's attraction for the electrons of a covalent bond
The number of valence electrons in an atom
The energy required to break a chemical bond
questions.correctAnswer: An atom's attraction for the electrons of a covalent bond

questions.text: In a nonpolar covalent bond, how are electrons shared?
In a polar covalent bond, how are electrons shared?
What is an ion?
choices: A molecule with a covalent bond
An atom or molecule with an electrical charge due to the loss or gain of electrons
questions.correctAnswer: An atom or molecule with an electrical charge due to the loss or gain of electrons

questions.text: What is an ionic bond?
choices: The sharing of electrons between atoms
The attraction between an anion and a cation
A bond formed by shared hydrogen atoms
questions.correctAnswer: The attraction between an anion and a cation

questions.text: What is a cation?
What is an anion?
What is a hydrogen bond?
choices: A bond between hydrogen and carbon atoms
A bond that forms when a hydrogen atom covalently bonded to one electronegative atom is attracted to another electronegative atom nearby
A strong bond formed by shared electrons
questions.correctAnswer: A bond that forms when a hydrogen atom covalently bonded to one electronegative atom is attracted to another electronegative atom nearby

questions.text: What are chemical reactions?
choices: The making and breaking of chemical bonds
The dissolving of substances in water
questions.correctAnswer: The making and breaking of chemical bonds

questions.text: What are reactants in a chemical reaction?
choices: The final molecules of a reaction
The molecules that speed up a reaction
The starting molecules of a chemical reaction
The waste products of a reaction
questions.correctAnswer: The starting molecules of a chemical reaction

questions.text: Why is understanding the chemical characteristics of water central to biology?
choices: Because water is a minor component of living organisms
Because water is a versatile solvent
Because basic concepts of physics do not apply to the study of life
questions.correctAnswer: Because water is a versatile solvent

questions.text: What kind of molecule is water?
What kind of charge does the oxygen region of a water molecule have?
What kind of charge does the hydrogen region of a water molecule have?
What type of bond holds two water molecules together?
What are the four emergent properties of water that contribute to Earth's suitability for life?
choices: Cohesive behavior, ability to moderate temperature, expansion upon freezing, and versatility as a solvent
High density, low specific heat, transparency, and acidity
Flammability, toxicity, radioactivity, and high viscosity
Inertness, non-polarity, and inability to dissolve salts
questions.correctAnswer: Cohesive behavior, ability to moderate temperature, expansion upon freezing, and versatility as a solvent

questions.text: What is cohesion in the context of water molecules?
choices: The linking of multiple water molecules by hydrogen bonds
questions.correctAnswer: The linking of multiple water molecules by hydrogen bonds

questions.text: What is adhesion in the context of water molecules?
choices: The clinging of one substance to another
The linking of multiple water molecules by hydrogen bonds
questions.correctAnswer: The clinging of one substance to another

questions.text: How does cohesion due to hydrogen bonding contribute to the transport of water in plants?
choices: By helping to transport water and nutrients against gravity
By dissolving minerals in the soil
questions.correctAnswer: By helping to transport water and nutrients against gravity

questions.text: What is surface tension?
choices: A measure of the average speed of water molecules
The force of attraction between water and air
A measure of how hard it is to break the surface of a liquid
The pressure exerted by water on its container
questions.correctAnswer: A measure of how hard it is to break the surface of a liquid

questions.text: How does water moderate temperature?
choices: By absorbing heat from warmer air and releasing stored heat to cooler air
By conducting heat away from organisms
questions.correctAnswer: By absorbing heat from warmer air and releasing stored heat to cooler air

questions.text: What is specific heat?
choices: The heat required to melt a substance
The energy released when a substance freezes
The amount of heat that must be absorbed or lost for 1 g of a substance to change its temperature by 1°C
The heat required to boil a substance
questions.correctAnswer: The amount of heat that must be absorbed or lost for 1 g of a substance to change its temperature by 1°C

questions.text: What is the specific heat of water?
Why does water resist changing its temperature?
choices: Because of its high specific heat
Because it does not absorb heat
Because it is not affected by temperature
questions.correctAnswer: Because of its high specific heat

questions.text: What happens to hydrogen bonds when water is heated?
What is heat of vaporization?
choices: The energy released when a liquid freezes
The heat a liquid must absorb for 1 g to be converted to gas
The energy required to melt a solid
The heat released when a gas condenses
questions.correctAnswer: The heat a liquid must absorb for 1 g to be converted to gas

questions.text: What is evaporative cooling?
choices: The process by which a liquid heats up as it evaporates
The process by which a liquid's remaining surface cools as it evaporates
The process by which a solid turns directly into a gas
The process by which a gas turns into a liquid
questions.correctAnswer: The process by which a liquid's remaining surface cools as it evaporates

questions.text: Why does ice float on liquid water?
choices: Because ice is denser than water
Because hydrogen bonds in ice are more 'ordered,' making ice less dense
Because ice is warmer than water
Because ice has no hydrogen bonds
questions.correctAnswer: Because hydrogen bonds in ice are more 'ordered,' making ice less dense

questions.text: What is a solution?
choices: A substance that cannot be dissolved
A liquid that is a homogeneous mixture of substances
A substance consisting of one element
questions.correctAnswer: A liquid that is a homogeneous mixture of substances

questions.text: What is a hydrophobic substance?
choices: A substance that has an affinity for water
A substance that easily dissolves in water
A substance that does not have an affinity for water
A substance that is ionic and polar
questions.correctAnswer: A substance that does not have an affinity for water

questions.text: What is the internal pH of most living cells?
What are buffers?
choices: Substances that increase the concentration of H+ in a solution
Substances that minimize changes in concentrations of H+ and OH- in a solution
Substances that have no effect on pH
Strong acids that completely dissociate in water
questions.correctAnswer: Substances that minimize changes in concentrations of H+ and OH- in a solution

questions.text: What do most buffer solutions contain?
choices: A strong acid and a strong base
A weak acid and a strong base
A weak acid and its corresponding base
questions.correctAnswer: A weak acid and its corresponding base

questions.text: How do buffer solutions minimize changes in pH?
choices: By permanently removing H+ and OH- from the solution

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a buffer that contributes to pH stability in human blood?
What happens when there is a rise in pH in the blood?
What happens when there is a drop in pH in the blood?
What is the pH of a neutral solution?
What is the pH of an acidic solution?
What is the pH of a basic solution?
What is the effect of acids on the H+ concentration in water?
choices: Acids have no effect on the H+ concentration

questions.text: What is the effect of bases on the H+ concentration in water?
choices: Bases have no effect on the H+ concentration
Bases neutralize H+ ions by producing more H+ ions

questions.text: Which of the following is true about strong acids?
choices: They do not dissociate in water

questions.text: Which of the following is true about strong bases?
choices: They dissociate partially to form hydroxide ions
They do not dissociate in water
They dissociate completely to form hydroxide ions
They increase the concentration of H+ ions
questions.correctAnswer: They dissociate completely to form hydroxide ions

questions.text: What is the role of hydroxide ions (OH-) in a basic solution?
choices: Combine with H+ ions to form water
Have no effect on H+ concentration
questions.correctAnswer: Combine with H+ ions to form water

questions.text: What is the pH range of most biological fluids?
How does human activity threaten water quality?
choices: By increasing the pH of water
By decreasing the pH of water
By having no impact on pH
By neutralizing all acids and bases
questions.correctAnswer: By decreasing the pH of water

questions.text: What is ocean acidification?
choices: The increase in ocean pH due to CO2 absorption
The decrease in ocean pH due to CO2 absorption
questions.correctAnswer: The decrease in ocean pH due to CO2 absorption

questions.text: Why is ocean acidification a concern?
choices: Because it benefits organisms that build coral reefs
Because it increases the availability of carbonate ions
Because it harms organisms that require carbonate ions
Because it has no effect on marine life
questions.correctAnswer: Because it harms organisms that require carbonate ions

questions.text: What happens to carbonate ions as seawater acidifies?
choices: They combine with hydrogen ions to form bicarbonate ions
questions.correctAnswer: They combine with hydrogen ions to form bicarbonate ions

questions.text: What element are living organisms primarily made of?
What is a compound containing carbon called?
What are the four main classes of organic molecules that are critically important to living things?
What is a large molecule consisting of many similar building blocks called?
What are the small building-block molecules that make up polymers called?
What process do cells use to make polymers from monomers, involving the loss of a water molecule?
What process do cells use to break down polymers into monomers by adding a water molecule?
What class of organic molecules includes sugars and polymers of sugars?
What are the simplest carbohydrates called?
What type of bond is formed when a dehydration reaction joins two monosaccharides?
What are carbohydrate macromolecules, polymers composed of many sugar building blocks, called?
Which polysaccharide is a major component of the tough walls that enclose plant cells?
What are fats constructed from?
What smaller molecules are phospholipids composed of?
choices: Two fatty acids and a phosphate group attached to glycerol
Three fatty acids attached to glycerol
questions.correctAnswer: Two fatty acids and a phosphate group attached to glycerol

questions.text: What are the major constituents of cell membranes?
What functions do proteins perform?
choices: Defense, storage, transport, and cellular communication
Act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions

questions.text: What are the monomers that build polypeptides?
What type of bond links amino acids to form a polypeptide?
What programs the amino acid sequence of a polypeptide?
What are genes made of?
